findings.title: Lack of permission check in function setFactory()
findings.description:
The function setFactory() in the NoahV3PoolDeployer contract allows setting the factory address used for pool deployment. 
1. **Description:** This function is intended to initialize the factory address but does not restrict access to privileged accounts.
2. **Cause:** The function lacks proper access control checks, relying only on a one-time initialization guard (require(factory == address(0))). Once the factory is set, it cannot be changed, but any external account can call this function before it is initialized.
3. **Exploitation:** An attacker can front-run the legitimate deployment transaction or exploit a delay in initialization to set a malicious factory address, thereby gaining control over future pool deployments.
4. **Impact:** If a malicious factory is set, the legitimate protocol factory may lose control over pool creation, potentially leading to the deployment of fraudulent pools and disruption of the entire protocol's functionality.
